awd_titl_txt: Studies in the Climate Dynamics of Moist Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
The moist processes which determine whether and how much it rains are central topics in climate dynamics, and a better understanding of how they operate could have substantial practical value. Such processes generally operate on the small spatial scales  and fast time scales found within clouds, yet they occur in response to large-scale slowly varying atmospheric conditions. The dependence of the fast, small-scale precipitation process on ambient conditions offers hope that their behavior can be understood, at least in a statistical or average sense, as a function of slower variations of temperature, moisture, and other factors occurring over the regions in which the moist processes occur.  This project strives to develop a theoretical understanding of the statistics of such moist processes, primarily in the case of convective precipitation in warm tropical environments. Specific issues to be considered include precipitation onset and its relationship to total column water vapor (CWV), non-normal behavior of precipitation probability, the frequency of occurrence of precipitation events of a given magnitude (as defined by total accumulated precipitation at a specific location), and the dependence of precipitation properties on parameters like the rate of entrainment of dry air into clouds.

Motivation for the work comes from the PI's previous work showing that the behavior of tropical convective precipitation can be simply encapsulated through rescaling techniques, for example by identifying a temperature-dependent value of CWV beyond which rain rate increases dramatically with increasing CWV.  When precipitation is considered as a function of CWV, it becomes apparent that the increase in rain rate with CWV follows the same curve over a wide range of temperatures, only with a temperature-dependent offset, so that the temperature dependence can be factored out by considering rain rate as a function of the ratio of CWV to its critical value.  The PI argues that this sort of rescaling can be quite helpful for developing fundamental insights into the behavior of moist processes and their dependence on ambient conditions.

The work in the proposal is organized into four themes: 1) fast-process diagnostics for moist processes, especially for precipitation onset and termination processes; 2) theory and hierarchical modeling for precipitation processes interacting with the large-scale flow in the dynamic neighborhood of convective quasi-equilibrium; 3) contributions to assessing moist process sensitivity to climate variability and change; and 4) development of observational constraints on moist processes to reduce structural uncertainty in model simulations.  The work includes a combination of diagnostic analysis of observations and climate model output (from the Community Earth System Model, CESM), parameter sensitivity experiments in CESM, and the development and use of simple stochastic models.  In one stochastic model the frequency of occurrence of rainfall events of a given magnitude is computed as a function of moisture convergence into the atmospheric column, so that changes in the probability of extreme events can be determined as a function of large-scale climate variability and change.

The work has broader impacts due to the importance of understanding how the statistics of precipitation, including the likelihood of extreme precipitation events and droughts, varies due to changes in ambient conditions such as those that are associated with El Nino events and secular climate change.  In addition, the work seeks to develop understanding of the dependence of moist processes on ambient conditions that can be used to develop better models for weather predictions and climate projections.

por.por_cntn:
Atmospheric moist processes are among the most important for producing societal impacts, from extreme weather events such as droughts and floods to their essential role in maintaining current climate. At the same time, they remain among the most challenging to accurately simulate in the large computational models used to predict weather and climate. Understanding these processes helps to refine the way these processes are represented in the computational models and to assess the reliability of projected changes in the hydrological cycle.

The work under this grant combined: mathematical theory for understanding processes, development of new diagnostics using multi-instrument observations, and analysis of computer model simulations to evaluate their representation of moist processes and to project precipitation changes.

One significant contribution was developing theory to understand the probability distribution of precipitation event accumulations, i.e., the amount of rainfall that accumulates from the start of precipitation to the end of the event. This theory has substantial implications for how the largest events change under climate warming, with the probability of large events increasing relative to historical climate---an increase that goes up exponentially with the size of the event. Evaluation of accumulation changes in climate models with increases in greenhouse gas is consistent with the form predicted by this theory. Evaluation of accumulation probability distributions from hourly observations across the US indicates that changes between recent and previous 1.5-decade periods follow the same form. Furthermore, the form of daily precipitation probability distributions can be understood from the event-accumulation distribution combined with dry intervals in between events.

Another significant contribution was the first evaluation of probability distributions of precipitation integrated across spatially continuous clusters in climate models compared to observations. Intriguingly, the probability distribution of precipitation spatial clusters has underlying similarities to the distribution of precipitation accumulations. A theoretical explanation developed for the spatial cluster distribution provides guidance on the dominant processes that yield large clusters. Assessment of changes in probabilities of large spatial clusters in model projections under climate warming exhibits an analogous change in probability, with the largest increases for the largest clusters. Pragmatic applications of this understanding include a collaboration to assess the likelihood of a recurrence of an event similar to the 1861-62 flood in California, estimated to have costs potentially approaching $1 trillion if it occurred today. Evaluation of a large ensemble of climate model simulations suggests that under business-as-usual greenhouse gas emissions, the probability of such a 200-year event occurring between now and mid-century would be as likely as not.

A key feature identified in the theory for precipitation distributions is a rapid change in the expected precipitation as a function of increasing water vapor for a given temperature. In observations, this transition is very sharp, associated with the onset of conditional instability that gives rise to deep convection, i.e, thunderstorm-like rainfall features. A set of diagnostics for assessing this transition in models in comparison to observations suggest that this is one of the areas that some models do well in, while others do poorly. Since weather and climate models do not resolve the small scales characterizing deep convection, they depend on representations of this transition as a function of large-scale temperature and moisture. Our diagnostics aid identification of which representations work well. A series of papers examining data from satellites, radiosondes, microwave radiometers, and in situ rain gauges suggested that an important effect for a good representation was for the rising cloud parcels to incorporate air from their environment. Dry air in the layer between 1-4 km then tends to reduce the buoyancy, killing convection, yielding a sharp transition to strong convection once this layer is moistened. This hypothesis was then substantiated and refined by two other studies from this project. One used a vertically pointed radar to estimate the mass flux in deep convective clouds and thus directly estimate the air entering the updrafts, while the other used big-data methods to infer the amount of air entering from the thermodynamic properties of profiles associated with strong convection. These complementary approaches yielded consistent answers: air at all levels below about 4 km has roughly equal influence on the convection, a significant departure from previous assumptions that air rising from the lowest levels was only slightly modified.

Other contributions include developing tools to assess trade-offs between different measures in assessing climate models, to understand the effect of weather noise on El Nino variations, and to evaluate the role of dynamical feedbacks in increasing precipitation extreme events.

This project contributed to the development of the nation's pool of trained STEM researchers, supporting 4 PhD graduates and helping to support postdocs and researchers to develop excellence in young scientists. The results of this research help to inform the PIs graduate classes and development of a new project-based undergraduate course by the PI.
